marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Patrick Henry was a patriot and statesman, from Hanover County, Virginia.

Miscellaneous papers including commissions; land grants; a letter from David Mason discussing the progress of his march to South Carolina and the men and supplies under his command; a circular letter to the members of the Pittsylvania County (Va.) county court, concerning the administration of taxes and pensions in Virginia; a printed letter from Henry listing the duties of a lieutenant in raising and provisioning his troops; a clipping comparing Henry and Thomas Jefferson; and a clipping, 1897, describing Henry's burial place and relics of Henry's that were owned by his grandson, William Wirt Henry.
William Heth was customs collector for Bermuda Hundred (Charles City County), Virginia.

Papers include circulars issued to collectors, instructions regarding sea letters and passports, regulations for arming merchant vessels, comments on recapture of American vessels from the French and strained relations with France, and a list of vessels registered and licensed in 1797.
Contact Research Services, Rubenstein Library, Duke University Library, Durham, NC 27708.
Letters of the John and Francis C. Herbert concerning efforts to collect from the federal government the claims of their father, Thomas Herbert, Revolutionary naval captain, for half pay for life.
James Vernor Henry was a resident of Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
Records of the contested will of Benjamin Vernor, of which James V. Henry was the beneficiary.
Joseph Henry was the first director of the Smithsonian Institution; resident of Washington, D.C.
Miscellaneous papers, including several letters pertaining to the administration of the Smithsonian.
Edward Thomas Heriot was a prominent planter and slaveowner of Georgetown (Georgetown County), South Carolina.

Collection contains Heriot's letters describing his trip to Great Britain, his voyage across the Atlantic to New York, his railroad trip to South Carolina, personal affairs, and his various estates and slaves. Also included is a defense of slavery and a criticism of abolition, Harriet Beecher Stowe, and Fredrika Bremer.

Gustavus A. Henry was an assistant adjutant general with the Confederate Army of Tennessee in 1861. He later became a colonel and in February 1865, was stationed at Augusta, Georgia, where he was in the Inspector General's Office.
Military dispatches of Gustavus A. Henry, commenting on troop movements and the conditions of roads in South Carolina in 1865.
J. L. Henry was a Confederate soldier from Virginia.

Civil War letters of a Confederate soldier discussing personal affairs, various Union and Confederate generals and units, Union prisoners, Confederate and Union casualties, desertions, and troop movements and engagements, including campaigns in Maryland and Pennsylvania, the sieges of Vicksburg and Richmond, and the battle of Cedar Run, 1862.
John Herr was a corporal, 94th Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry, from Donnelsville (Clark County), Ohio.

Letters describing troop movements across the Georgia mountains in 1863, commodity prices, Confederate evacuation of breastworks at Resaca, Georgia, voting for Abraham Lincoln for president, the desire to devastate South Carolina in retaliation for having initiated hostilities, the burning of Atlanta, and the march from Savannah, Georgia, to Fayetteville, North Carolina. Herr criticized his "treasonous" family for showing sympathy for the Confederacy. Also included are references to financial affairs in Ohio.
W. F. Henderson was a resident of Charlotte, Mecklenburg County, North Carolina.
Letters and documents concerning an equity case involving the purchase of cotton, submitted to the military authorities because of the lack of adequate civilian facilities.
Francis W. Henry was a resident of Byhalia, Mississippi.
Letters from Francis W. Henry, collector for B. E. Wofford and J. Frank Wofford, concerning the collection of private debts during Reconstruction.
O. Henry, pseudonym of William Sydney Porter, was an author, from Greensboro (Guilford County), North Carolina.

Includes a letter from O. Henry to George Rathborne explaining how the name "Rathborne" happened to be chosen by Henry for a character in a story; and letters addressed to Henry Wysham Lanier, secretary of Doubleday, Page & Co., on matters of publication, financial and business affairs, and the author's health.
Published in part in Clarence Cohdes, "Some letters by O. Henry," South Atlantic Quarterly, XXXIII (Jan. 1939), 31-39.
